title: ACLED Conflict Analysis Methodology
description: Core ACLED methodology for conflict event categorization, actor classification, and fatality verification

battles.description: Violent interactions where armed groups exchange lethal force

protests.description: Public demonstrations organized by political groups, civil society, or individuals

riots.description: Spontaneous or loosely organized violent public disorder

explosions_remote_violence.description: Violent events where the main tactic involves remote explosives or ranged weapons

violence_against_civilians.description: Violent events where civilians are the primary targets

strategic_developments.description: Non-violent political or military events that significantly affect conflict dynamics

event_taxonomy.hierarchy_rules: Higher-level events absorb lower-level concurrent tactics to avoid double-counting

1.name: State Forces
1.description: Military, police, and government-recognized security forces

2.name: Rebel Groups
2.description: Armed groups seeking to overthrow government or gain independence

3.name: Political Militias
3.description: Armed groups aligned with political parties or leaders

5.name: Rioters
5.description: Disorganized crowds engaged in spontaneous violence

6.name: Protesters
6.description: Organized groups engaged in public demonstration

8.name: External/Other Forces
8.description: Foreign state forces or international actors

interaction_codes.coding_method: Standardized order regardless of Actor 1/Actor 2 sequence

repression.definition: State violence against civilians or protesters
repression.criteria: State forces (type 1) interacting with civilians (type 7) or protesters (type 6)

insurgency.criteria: Any event with rebel group (interaction code 2)
insurgency.scope: Includes battles, VTC, strategic developments, abductions, looting
insurgency.purpose: Comprehensive view of rebel activity beyond traditional battles

atrocities.criteria: Violence against civilians events with 10+ reported fatalities
atrocities.methodology: Conservative fatality coding ensures significance threshold

terrorist_activity.definition: Systematic civilian targeting by armed groups

designation_process.step1: Calculate global VTC baseline for non-state actors annually
designation_process.step2: Groups exceeding baseline rate AND involved in 50+ events/year
designation_process.step3: All events involving designated groups tagged as terrorist activity
designation_process.recalculation: Annual January recalculation based on prior year behavior

foreign_military_engagement.definition: State military actions outside domestic territory
examples: Israeli forces with Hezbollah in Lebanon

fatality_verification.minimum_reporting: Only fatalities with reasonable certainty included
fatality_verification.atrocities_threshold: 10+ fatalities for VTC events to qualify as atrocities

key_actor_types: Rebel Groups (IPOB, ESN, Boko Haram factions)

common_event_patterns.insurgency: Southeast separatist movements, Northeast extremist groups
common_event_patterns.atrocities: Mass killings in communal conflicts, terrorist attacks

analysis_guidelines.event_categorization: Apply hierarchy rules to avoid double-counting concurrent tactics
analysis_guidelines.actor_classification: Focus on organizational structure and goals, not just tactics
analysis_guidelines.fatality_reporting: Use conservative approach, verify multiple sources when possible
analysis_guidelines.conflict_category_application: Apply categories systematically based on defined criteria
analysis_guidelines.nigerian_context: Consider ethnic, religious, political dynamics in actor motivations

quality_assurance.source_requirements: Minimum 2 independent sources for high-confidence events
quality_assurance.spatial_precision: Geocode to most specific location available
quality_assurance.actor_naming: Use recognized names, generate only when necessary with clear rationale
